pre_consent_screens: <div><h4>Centre for Digital Music, School of Electronics Engineering and
Computer Science, Queen Mary University of London
Title of Study: Facilitating Intuitive Sound Design:
FM Synthesis Experiment
Names of researchers: Ben Hayes, Charalampos Saitis
This study has been approved by the Queen Mary Ethics of Research Committee (ref: QMREC2352a)
<hr>
Dear Participant,
We would like to invite you to be part of this research project,
if you would like to. You should only agree to take part if you want
to; it is entirely up to you. If you choose not to take part, there
won’t be any disadvantages for you and you will hear no more about
it.
Please read the following information carefully before you decide to
take part. This will tell you why the research is being done and
what you will be asked to do if you take part. Please ask if there
is anything that is not clear or if you would like more information.
You are still free to withdraw at any time and without giving a
reason.
This study is part of a piece of research into how sounds
from synthesisers are perceived, and how this information can
be used to help create new interfaces for creative sound
design.
In this study you will be asked to design sounds in response
to descriptive words, using a computer-based synthesiser. You
will also be asked to complete a questionnaire to assess your
musical background. By agreeing to take part, you grant the
researcher permission (a license) to use any sounds you design
as part of the study in the following ways:
<ol><li>The sounds you design may be used in a future study
with other participants to perform another type of listening
test.
<li>The sounds you design may be used to train machine
learning models.
<li>The sounds you design may be released as part of a
dataset for scientific use, or stored in a data repository for
open access and sharing.
Any data you share will be coded so that you are not
identifiable if disclosed to third parties.
It is up to you to decide whether to take part. If you do decide to
take part, you will be asked to give your consent.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
Please read Queen Mary’s privacy notice for research participants
for important information about your personal data and your rights
in this respect.
If you have any questions relating to data protection, please

pre_demo_screens: Welcome to the study, and thank you for agreeing to take part.
In this study you will be asked to program a synthesiser to create sounds in response to some descriptive words.
The following pages contain instructions on how to complete the experiment. Please read them carefully.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
In order to complete the study, you must be using the latest version of the Google Chrome browser on a laptop or desktop computer.
You should also use headphones or reference monitor speakers.
Please do not attempt to complete the study using laptop speakers.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
Before continuing, we must adjust the volume of your listening apparatus.
Please ensure that no other sound is playing on your computer and follow these steps carefully.
First, turn down your computer volume until it makes no sound.
It is important to reduce the volume rather than simply pressing mute.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
Click play on the audio player below. Once started, the player will loop automatically.
Now, gradually increase your computer's volume until the white noise is at a comfortable listening level.
It is important that you do not change your computer's volume for the rest of the experiment.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
When the experiment starts, you will be presented with a simple FM synthesiser, which will already be programmed to produce a sound.
Above the synthesiser, you will see an instruction to alter the sound in some way. For example, you might be asked to make a sound brighter, or less rough.
Your task is to alter the parameters of the synthesiser in order to match the description given. You may take as much time as you wish to achieve this, and alter the sound as much as you wish.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
The synthesiser is a three operator FM synthesiser.
The operators are organised according to the following algorithm:
This means that operator one is the carrier, and operators two and three both directly modulate its frequency.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
On the next screen, you will be able to practice making a sound with the synthesiser.
Please take as much time as you need to familiarise yourself with the controls.
You can play the sound you have created by pressing the C key on your keyboard.
Pressing the R key will play back the starting sound (the reference sound).
Once you are finished, you can click the submit button to move on.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
post_demo_screens: After you have submitted your sound, you will be asked some questions about the sound you have created.
There is no right or wrong response to these questions. Please simply answer to the best of your ability.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
You will be asked to create 9 sounds. Once you are done, you will be asked a few short questions.
Remember, the C key plays back the sound you have created and the R key plays back the reference sound.
The experiment will begin on the next screen. When you are ready, press any key to start.
post_experiment_screens: The synthesis portion of the experiment is now complete.
On the following screen, you will be asked a few short questions about yourself.
Please answer these to the best of your ability.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
post_questionnaire_screens: The experiment is now complete. Thank you for taking part.
It is now safe to close your browser tab.
